verses.text: My child, have you sinned? Do not do it again, but pray for forgiveness for your past faults.
verses.comment: The verse presents repentance as immediate and practical: avoid repeating sin, and ask for forgiveness. This reflects the biblical pattern of confession and turning away from wrongdoing (see also Prov. 28:13; 1 John 1:9).

verses.text: Flee from sin as you would from a serpent, for if you approach, it will bite you; its teeth are like those of a lion, killing the souls of people.
verses.comment: Sin is portrayed as deadly and aggressive—its effect is spiritual death. Avoidance and vigilance are stressed, echoing imagery like the serpent in Genesis 3 and spiritual warnings in Revelation.

verses.text: Every transgression is like a two-edged sword; there is no healing for its wound.
verses.comment: Sin's consequences cut deeply, and natural healing is impossible apart from God’s mercy, pointing to the need for spiritual forgiveness.

verses.text: Terror and violence will lay waste riches; so the house of the proud will be made desolate.
verses.comment: Pride is connected to ruin—a recurring biblical principle. Both the Old and New Testaments warn against pride for individuals and societies.

verses.text: Supplication from a poor man’s mouth reaches the ears of God, and his judgment comes quickly.
verses.comment: God hears the humble and oppressed speedily, a theme fulfilled in Christ’s teaching on prayer and justice (cf. Luke 18:7).

verses.text: Whoever hates correction walks in the footsteps of a sinner; but whoever fears the Lord will repent in his heart.
verses.comment: Rejection of correction increases sinful behavior; the fear of God prompts true repentance, as Jesus also taught at the beginning of his ministry.

verses.text: A talkative man is known everywhere; but the thoughtful know when to remain quiet.
verses.comment: Self-mastery over speech is celebrated throughout Scripture (see Proverbs and James). Discipline of the tongue is a traditional sign of holiness.

verses.text: Whoever builds his house with others’ money is like one who gathers stones for his own burial.
verses.comment: Illicit gain leads to ruin and death, not real security, recalling warnings about unjust wealth from the prophets and wisdom literature.

verses.text: A gathering of the wicked is like tinder gathered for a fire; their end is a flame.
verses.comment: The destructiveness of evil associations is emphasized. Jesus' parable of the weeds (Matt. 13) picks up this imagery, pointing to final judgment.

verses.text: The way of sinners is smoothly paved, but it leads to the depths of Sheol.
verses.comment: Sin often seems easy and attractive, but ends in destruction—a wisdom motif. Jesus warned similarly of the 'wide gate' (Matt. 7:13).

verses.text: Whoever keeps the law controls his own thoughts, and the accomplishment of the fear of the Lord is wisdom.
verses.comment: Obedience to the law brings alignment of mind and reverent wisdom, closely linking adherence to God’s commands with inner transformation.

verses.text: He who is not clever will not be taught, but there is a cleverness that increases bitterness.
verses.comment: Teachability is a virtue. Yet, mere cleverness—absent of humility—can be dangerous. Paul warns similarly about 'knowledge puffing up' (1 Cor. 8:1).

verses.text: The knowledge of the wise will overflow like a river, and his counsel will spring forth like a fountain of life.
verses.comment: True wisdom is life-giving, connecting with Christ’s promise of living water (John 4:14), indicating both instruction and grace.

verses.text: The heart of the fool is like a broken jar; it will not retain any knowledge.
verses.comment: Those who reject wisdom cannot hold truth; imagery of cracked vessels appears throughout Scripture for spiritual barrenness.

verses.text: If a wise person hears a word, he will praise it and add to it; when a scoffer hears it, he dislikes and throws it away.
verses.comment: Teachability distinguishes the wise; Jesus uses similar language about those given much being able to receive more (Matt. 13:12).

verses.text: Talking with a fool is like carrying a sleeping man: in the end, it will become a burden.
verses.comment: Efforts to instruct the foolish can be fruitless and frustrating—a recurring biblical warning about discernment in teaching.

verses.text: A fool laughs aloud, but a wise person smiles quietly.
verses.comment: Controlled demeanor and humility are associated with wisdom; loose, loud joy can signal folly.

verses.text: Instruction is like a gold ornament for the discerning, and like a bracelet on the right arm.
verses.comment: Instruction is beautiful and sets one apart like precious jewelry—a clear parallel to Proverbs.

verses.text: The foot of a fool rushes quickly into a house, but a well-mannered person stands outside respectfully.
verses.comment: The wise show respect and humility, echoing Jesus’ teaching about places of honor and humility in Luke.

verses.text: A rude person peers into a house, but a well-trained person will remain outside.
verses.comment: Courtesy and discipline are extolled—manners reflect inner virtue, another key biblical value.

verses.text: It is rude for some to listen at the door; the prudent will be weighed down with shame.
verses.comment: The text reaffirms that respect for privacy and refusal to gossip are central to wisdom.

verses.text: The lips of strangers will speak against these things, but the words of the prudent will be weighed in the balance.
verses.comment: External judgment is contrasted with a wise self-control that seeks honesty and truth.

verses.text: The mind of fools is in their mouth, but the mouth of the wise is in their mind.
verses.comment: This antithesis highlights that wisdom governs speech, while folly speaks impulsively.

verses.text: When the ungodly curse their adversary, they curse their own soul.
verses.comment: Evil intentions return harm to the sender, a theme also found in Proverbs and the Psalms.

verses.text: A whisperer slanders himself and will be hated wherever he goes.
verses.comment: Gossip destroys reputations—especially the speaker’s own—a proverb echoed frequently throughout wisdom literature.

verses.text: A lazy person is likened to a lump of filth, and everyone who touches him will shake off his hands.
verses.comment: Laziness leads to isolation and disgrace; Scripture consistently urges diligence as a sign of uprightness.

verses.text: The prayer of a slanderer is detested by the Lord, and He will only multiply his punishment.
verses.comment: Insincerity in prayer, especially from those who harbor evil, is rejected by God—a motif also in the prophets. Right action precedes true prayer.

verses.text: The words of one who deceives others hide his faults, but a wise person corrects his own errors.
verses.comment: The wise embrace correction and confession of faults, in harmony with Jesus’ teaching on self-examination and mercy. The principle of confession and amendment of life is a mark of spiritual maturity.
